questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus.
  • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus.
  • T11, T12 - supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region.
  • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.

questions.text: During the abdominal examination of a patient, you notice the following pattern of subcutaneous venous circulation.  In which of the following conditions is this pattern seen?
questions.solution:
The pattern of subcutaneous venous circulation depicted in the image can be seen in cases of inferior vena caval obstruction.

The level of the umbilicus is a watershed area for venous and lymphatic circulation. The systemic veins anastomose with tributaries of portal veins at the umbilicus. Normally, venous blood and lymphatics flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus and downwards below this plane. 

Disease Pattern of blood flow in anterior abdominal wall veins
Inferior vena cava obstruction Completely upwards
Superior vena cava obstruction Completely downwards
Portal hypertension Radiating away from the umbilicus like a star (caput-medusae)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman having lower abdominal pain and shock is diagnosed with a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. The gynecologist decides to perform an emergency laparotomy via the incision shown in the image below. Which of these structures is not incised in this approach?
questions.solution:
The image shows a midline incision used for emergency laparotomy. Transversus abdominis muscle is not incised in this approach.

Layers of the abdomen pierced in the midline approach (from superficial to deep):

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Campers and Scarpa)
  • Linea alba
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

There are no muscles pierced in this approach. 

Layers of the abdomen pierced in the flanks (from superficial to deep):

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Campers and Scarpa)
  • External oblique
  • Internal oblique
  • Transversus abdominis
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

These layers are shown in the image below:

Clinical Note: Umbilical and epigastric hernias can happen due to a congenital or acquired defect in the linea alba such as a midline abdominal incision.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man complains of weakness of his trunk muscles following a stroke.  While examining the patient, you ask him to perform the following movement. Which of the following muscles is/are being tested here?

choices.text: Ipsilateral external oblique and contralateral internal oblique
Ipsilateral external oblique and internal oblique
Ipsilateral transversus abdominis and internal oblique

questions.solution:
The given image shows lateral flexion of the trunk being performed, which is done by the ipsilateral external oblique (EO) and internal oblique (IO) muscles.

The anterior abdominal wall comprises of 4 muscles:

  • External oblique
  • Internal oblique
  • Transversus abdominis
  • Rectus abdominis

Muscles involved in movements of the trunk include:

Action

Muscles involved

Forward flexion of trunk (lumbar spine)

Rectus abdominis and bilateral IO and EO

Lateral flexion of  the trunk

Ipsilateral IO and EO
Rotation of trunk

Ipsilateral IO and contralateral EO

Tensing the linea alba

Pyramidalis

Pulling the testes towards the superficial inguinal ring

Cremaster

questions.text: An anterior abdominal wall nerve block is to be performed for a patient with pain at the appendicectomy incision site.  What is the site of injection of the local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
The local anesthetic is injected between the internal oblique (marked as 2) and transversus abdominis (marked as 3) muscles in the anterior abdominal wall. This is because the neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between these two muscles.

The plane between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis contains:

  • Lower 6 thoracic nerves (T7-12)
  • Iliohypogastric nerves
  • Posterior intercostal and subcostal vessels
  • Anastomosis between superior and inferior epigastric arteries

The transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block is a regional anesthetic technique used for abdominal surgeries like open cholecystectomy, open appendicectomy, and hernia surgery. It is also used for postoperative analgesia after these surgeries.

questions.text: The given image of the rectus sheath represents a section at which of the following levels?

choices.text: Below a point midway between pubic symphysis and umbilicus
Between the umbilicus and arcuate line
Below a point midway between xiphisternum and pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The given image represents a transverse section through the rectus sheath below the arcuate line. The arcuate line is located midway between the umbilicus and pubic symphysis. 

The rectus sheath is formed from the aponeuroses of all three lateral abdominal muscles i.e. external oblique, internal oblique, and transversus abdominis. Each aponeurosis is bilaminar having 2 leaves. 

Rectus sheath above the arcuate line:

  • Anterior layer is composed of both leaves of the aponeurosis of the external oblique and the anterior leaf of the aponeurosis of the internal oblique.
  • Posterior layer is composed of the posterior leaf of the aponeurosis of the internal oblique and both leaves of the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis.

Rectus sheath below the arcuate line

  • Anterior layer is formed by the aponeurosis of all three muscles - external oblique, internal oblique, and transversus abdominis.
  • Posterior layer is deficient and the rectus abdominis muscle lies directly on the fascia transversalis.

questions.text: In the rectus sheath,  with which of the following arteries does the superior epigastric artery anastomose?

choices.text: Branch of superficial circumflex iliac artery

questions.solution:
In the rectus sheath, the superior epigastric artery anastomoses with the inferior epigastric artery, a branch of the external iliac artery.

The superior epigastric artery is a branch of the internal thoracic artery. They anastomose in the rectus sheath above the level of the umbilicus.

The image given below shows the anastomosis between the superior and inferior epigastric artery in the rectus sheath.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply for the structure marked X in the below image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is pyramidalis, which is supplied by the subcostal nerve (ventral ramus of T12).

The pyramidalis is a triangle-shaped muscle that runs within the rectus sheath. The base is attached to the anterosuperior margin of the pubis and to the ligamentous fibres in front of the symphysis. The apex is attached to the linea alba. 

It gets its nerve supply from the terminal branches of the subcostal nerve (the ventral ramus of T12). In some cases, it may be innervated wholly or partly by fibres from L1 travelling in the subcostal or ilioinguinal nerves. 

Related Pearl: Abdominal muscles and their nerve supplies

Muscles

Nerve supply

External oblique and rectus abdominis

T7-11 intercostal nerves and subcostal nerve

Internal oblique and transversus abdominis

T7-11 intercostal nerves, subcostal nerve and L1

Pyramidalis

Subcostal nerve (the anterior division of T12) 

Cremaster  (efferent for cremasteric reflex)

Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the boundaries of the inguinal canal is false?

choices.text: Anterior wall has external oblique aponeurosis along its entire length
Posterior wall has transversalis fascia along its entire length
Roof has the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle
External oblique is present in the anterior wall, roof, and posterior wall

questions.solution:
The external oblique is present only in the anterior wall of the inguinal canal. 

Internal oblique is present in the anterior wall in the lateral one-third (as muscular fibers), roof (as arched fibers), and posterior wall (as part of the conjoint tendon) of the inguinal canal.

Transversus abdominis is present as part of the roof and posterior wall (as the conjoint tendon)

 

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the contents of the inguinal canal is true?

choices.text: Internal spermatic fascia is derived from the fascia transversalis
Ilioinguinal nerve enters the canal at the deep inguinal ring
Cremasteric artery is a branch of superior epigastric artery
Indirect Inguinal hernias do not occur in women

questions.solution:
Internal spermatic fascia is a derivative of fascia transversalis.

External spermatic fascia is derived from external oblique aponeurosis. The cremasteric fascia is derived from internal oblique. 

Option B: The ilioinguinal nerve does not enter the inguinal canal at the deep inguinal ring. It enters the inguinal canal by piercing its posterior wall.

Option C: The cremasteric artery is a branch of the inferior epigastric artery.

Option D: Indirect inguinal hernias are seen in both men and women.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He was unable to pass urine and blood was seen at the tip of the urethra. A diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was made.  Where do you least expect the urine to get collected in this case?
questions.solution:
In bulbar urethral injury, the medial portion of the thigh is the least likely site for the collection of urine.

The rupture of the urethra below the urogenital diaphragm will result in extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch, penis and scrotum in males and labia majora in females, and the anterior abdominal wall.

The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided below the umbilicus into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and a deep membranous layer (fascia of Scarpa). Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). 

Colles' fascia is attached to fascia lata (the deep fascia of the thigh) along the Holden's line that extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. Extravasated fluid cannot pass into the medial thigh below Holden's line due to the firm attachment of Colles' fascia to the fascia lata.

questions.text: The image below shows the insertion of the transversus abdominis muscle. Identify the conjoint tendon.
questions.solution:
The structure marked 3 is the conjoint tendon. It is formed from the lower fibers of the internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis. It is attached to the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line.

Transversus Abdominis muscle:

Origin - from the internal surface of 7th-12th costal cartilages, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament.

Insertion - at the linea alba with the aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest, and pecten pubis via the conjoint tendon.
